And Moore's law says that every two years, the number of transistors on a chip is doubling. That's the graph that you've seen. And that leads to, let's say, this 30 million increase over a period of 50 years. And the interesting thing is that Moore's law applies to many things relevant for data science and for computing. So you can look at storage processing and...

communication. You can look at all of these fields. You can look at things becoming cheaper, things becoming faster, and things becoming smaller. And what is surprising, that in all of these different fields, you see exactly the same phenomenon. that it's even going faster. What you see is that if you look at the size of AI models over the last couple of years, it has been growing four times per year. So much faster than Moore's law. So this is not so easy. We tend to rely a lot on, let's say, automated algorithms. And this is an example that I often show. The data is a bit outdated, but the principle is still exactly the same. But if you would look at newer data, on the example data it will be almost flawless. Much better than you as a human would do it. But now I tell you one disturbing thing.

In these images, I typically only need to change two pixels and the neural network will change the decision from red to green or from green to red. So it works very well, but there are vulnerabilities that I just change the input just a small bit. You as a human would still see exactly the same picture. Nothing would have changed, but the decision would have swapped.

Not random. You look at... So the claim is here is that you... Because if it's random, it will have the same performance as before. No. If you know how the neural network works, you change two pixels, and that's enough to swap the thing. So that's also how you can hack these types of systems. for the neural network by just changing a bit. There are all kinds of tricks, right? And if you look at, let's say, accidents with self-driving cars, so for example, there can be a truck that has, I don't know, a stop sign printed on it, and it's moving. For you as a person, it's completely clear that that is not a stop sign. But for an AI, they just see a stop sign, right? And they will stop.

So that's the way it works. So it's amazing, but at the same time, let's say, as humans, we need to be able to interpret what these things are doing and what has happened. Another thing is that things work well if there is lots of training data. So self-driving cars are trained by lots and lots of different images, but there should be no changes.

And if you look at many problems where you would like to apply, let's say, these types of techniques, there are changes. So if you, for example, look at, I don't know, COVID, the supply chain crisis, et cetera, et cetera, it changed things completely. So I'm showing you this picture is that you have training data to train your system. But then if you put it into a new environment, it may not work at all.

It would be the same as that you would train Tesla cars, I don't know, in California, and then you suddenly start applying them, I don't know, in Rome. That would not work because it's out of distribution. And you can see if there is concept drift, so things are changing, that things like that do not work. So there is this shiny, let's say, outside of when we look at these techniques.

But if you look at the inside, there is often lots of engineering, lots of, let's say, possible problems that you need to address, and you need to know what you're doing. And that's why you are taking this course, that you understand these techniques, and that you can use, let's say, your human interpretation to look at these things. In this context, we often use the term hybrid intelligence.

And what we are seeing is that many tasks that were previously done by people are slowly being done by algorithms and hardware. But there is a balance between it. And for many tasks, it is best to use a combination. I talked earlier about that Jeffrey Hinton made this wrong estimate.

that we do not need doctors to interpret x-ray machines. And what you see is what works best is a combination of an algorithm and a doctor. So the algorithm is giving you diagnostics, it gives you x-ray information, is encouraging the doctor to look at particular things, but then the doctor can still better judge than the best algorithms. And that's this algorithm of hybrid.

This principle of hybrid intelligence where you try to combine the best of both modes. Data science has many dimensions, right? And I will show you in a minute a sheep with five legs, right? So a data scientist is like somebody that needs to have many different skills. And one of the reasons is that there are multiple dimensions that you need to deal with. So for example, there are different types of data.

There are tabular data. There are images. There is event data. There is time series data. In this course, there's also text data. So in this course, you will see all of these different types of data. Right? It's not one thing. There are different types of tasks. In a minute, I will talk about the difference between supervised and unsupervised. So supervised means that you are looking for something specific.

Unsupervised means that you want to be surprised. You want to learn something that you did not know before without looking for something specific. Is the machine doing it or is the human doing this? Related to that question is, are we using an algorithm or are we looking at the visualization? So there will be two lectures devoted to visualization.

And you will see surprising things that you with a human eye can see something in one millisecond that an algorithm is not able to pick up. And vice versa. Flexibility versus usability. So you will be using Python in this course. In Python, there are millions of different libraries that you can apply. So it's extremely flexible, but it's not supporting you.

in a lot of ways, right? You need to compose these different things. There may be dedicated tools which are much more usable by end users, but are, let's say, just there for a specific task. Scalability versus quality. It may be the case that I can give an approximate answer in half a second, and I can give a very precise answer by computing, let's say, two months.

What are you going to do? So many algorithms have trade-offs where you simply stop it if the quality is sufficient. And there is responsibility versus utility. So if you are willing to give up certain privacy aspects or certain fairness aspects, it may be that you get much better results. And that's another trade-off that we will look at.

very much at the end of this course. So this leads to sheep with five legs. So in the Dutch language, this is a very common expression, right?
